title: Isaiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 36 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 36.

questions.question: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, who came up against the defended cities of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Sennacherib king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:1 states that in the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the defended cities of Judah.

questions.question: From which city did the king of Assyria send Rabshakeh to Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Lachish
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:2 mentions that the king of Assyria sent Rabshakeh from Lachish to Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who came forth to meet Rabshakeh at the conduit of the upper pool?
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah
questions.explanation: According to Isaiah 36:3, Eliakim, Hilkiah's son, Shebna the scribe, and Joah, Asaph's son, the recorder, came forth to meet Rabshakeh.

questions.question: What did Rabshakeh say about trusting in Egypt?
options: It is like a broken reed that pierces the hand
It will protect Judah from war
It is the staff of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: It is like a broken reed that pierces the hand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:6 describes trusting in Egypt as relying on a broken reed that pierces the hand of the one who leans on it.

questions.question: True or False: Rabshakeh spoke to Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah in the Jewish language to prevent the people on the wall from understanding.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:11 shows that Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah asked Rabshakeh to speak in the Syrian language because they understood it, so the people on the wall would not understand. Rabshakeh refused and spoke in the Jewish language instead.

questions.question: What was the king of Assyria's claim about the LORD's involvement in his coming against Judah?
options: The LORD commanded me to go up and destroy this land
The LORD is powerless against me
The LORD is on the side of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD commanded me to go up and destroy this land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:10 states that Rabshakeh claimed the LORD said to him, 'Go up against this land, and destroy it.'

questions.question: What did Rabshakeh offer if Hezekiah set riders on horses?
questions.correctAnswer: Two thousand horses
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:8 records Rabshakeh offering two thousand horses if Hezekiah could set riders on them.

questions.question: According to Rabshakeh, what should the people do instead of trusting Hezekiah or the LORD?
options: Make an agreement with the king of Assyria and enjoy their own vineyards and waters
Pray to the gods of their fathers
questions.correctAnswer: Make an agreement with the king of Assyria and enjoy their own vineyards and waters
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:16 advises the people to make an agreement by a present and enjoy their vines, fig trees, and cistern waters instead of trusting Hezekiah.

questions.question: Who were the men that came to Hezekiah with their clothes rent after hearing Rabshakeh's words?
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:22 shows that Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah came to Hezekiah with their clothes rent to report Rabshakeh's words.

questions.question: True or False: Rabshakeh said Hezekiah has taken away the high places and altars of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:7 states that Rabshakeh accused Hezekiah of taking away the high places and altars of the LORD.

questions.question: What did Rabshakeh say would happen to the people on the wall if they listened to Hezekiah?
options: They would be deceived and not delivered
They would be saved and prosper
They would find peace with Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: They would be deceived and not delivered
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:14-15 records Rabshakeh's warning that Hezekiah would deceive them and would not be able to deliver the city.

questions.question: What was the response of the men on the wall to Rabshakeh's words?
options: They held their peace and answered him not a word
They sent a message to Egypt for help
questions.correctAnswer: They held their peace and answered him not a word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:21 states that the men held their peace and did not answer Rabshakeh because of the king's commandment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Rabshakeh stood and cried with a loud voice in the ______ language.
questions.correctAnswer: Jews'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:13 says Rabshakeh cried out with a loud voice in the Jews' language.

questions.question: What did Rabshakeh say about the gods of the nations compared to the LORD?
options: No gods of the nations delivered their lands from Assyria
The gods of the nations are more powerful than the LORD
The gods of Hamath and Arphad protected their lands
The gods of Sepharvaim rescue their people
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh blasphemously compared the LORD to the powerless gods of other nations, claiming none could deliver their people from Assyria.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 36 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 36, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God rather than worldly alliances?
options: Trust in God's power rather than relying on human strength or foreign alliances.
Rely mainly on military strength and political alliances for protection.
Ignore God's promises and focus on personal wisdom.
Trust only in material wealth for security.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's power rather than relying on human strength or foreign alliances.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:5-7 and 36:18 teach that trusting in Egypt or human counsel is like leaning on a broken reed, while true confidence should be in the LORD. This passage encourages faith in God's deliverance rather than worldly means.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 36 demonstrate the importance of humility when facing opposition?
options: By showing Hezekiah's officials listening quietly and not answering the enemy.
By boasting about their own military strength.
By rejecting any possibility of defeat.
By attacking the Assyrian army immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: By showing Hezekiah's officials listening quietly and not answering the enemy.
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 36:21, the officials remain silent as commanded by the king, showing humility and restraint in the face of provocation rather than arrogance or rashness.

questions.question: What does the passage teach about the danger of false confidence in human help?
options: Relying on Egypt is like leaning on a broken reed that pierces the hand.
Human help is always trustworthy and sufficient.
Military power is the ultimate source of security.
questions.correctAnswer: Relying on Egypt is like leaning on a broken reed that pierces the hand.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:6 uses the metaphor of a broken reed to describe the futility and danger of trusting Egypt for help, warning believers against false confidence in worldly supports.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to stand firm in faith during trials. What encouragement does Isaiah 36 offer regarding God's sovereignty over trials?
options: God commands even the enemy’s actions, so we can trust His control over circumstances.
Trials happen without God's knowledge or control.
We should avoid all trials by fleeing.
Trials mean God has abandoned us.
questions.correctAnswer: God commands even the enemy’s actions, so we can trust His control over circumstances.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:10 reveals that the king of Assyria came up against the land because the LORD said so, showing God’s sovereign control over trials and encouraging believers to trust Him in difficulties.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 36 teach about the importance of obedience to God's commands even under pressure?
options: Hezekiah’s officials obey the king’s command to remain silent despite provocation.
They respond angrily to the enemy’s insults.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah’s officials obey the king’s command to remain silent despite provocation.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:21 shows the officials' obedience to the king’s command not to answer Rabshakeh, reflecting disciplined faith and submission even in challenging situations.

questions.question: What lesson about faith and prayer can be drawn from Hezekiah’s response to the Assyrian threat in Isaiah 36?
options: Hezekiah seeks God’s counsel and does not put trust in foreign powers or empty threats.
He relies solely on military strength.
He ignores the threat and does nothing.
He makes a political alliance with Assyria.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah seeks God’s counsel and does not put trust in foreign powers or empty threats.
questions.explanation: While Isaiah 36 does not record Hezekiah’s prayer directly, his officials’ silence and rejection of Assyria’s boasts (Isaiah 36:21) indicate reliance on God rather than human help, teaching believers to trust God in prayer during trials.

questions.question: How can Isaiah 36 guide us in maintaining integrity and honesty when facing opposition or temptation?
options: By responding faithfully with truth and restraint rather than deceit or rash words.
By lying to the enemy to deceive them.
By boasting about our own strength.
By refusing to speak at all times.
questions.correctAnswer: By responding faithfully with truth and restraint rather than deceit or rash words.
questions.explanation: The officials’ silence (Isaiah 36:21) and the clear presentation of Rabshakeh’s words (Isaiah 36:4-20) show the importance of honesty and measured response, highlighting integrity in difficult situations.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 36, what is a key warning when facing spiritual or physical trials?
options: Do not be persuaded by false promises of deliverance from sources other than God.
Trust only in human intelligence for safety.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be persuaded by false promises of deliverance from sources other than God.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:18-20 warns about trusting in gods of other nations or foreign powers, emphasizing the importance of relying on the LORD alone for deliverance.

questions.question: When a believer faces discouragement, how does Isaiah 36 encourage perseverance through trials?
options: By showing that even in difficult situations, God’s plan is sovereign and will be fulfilled.
By advising to give up and surrender.
By ignoring the source of trouble.
By relying exclusively on human strength.
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that even in difficult situations, God’s plan is sovereign and will be fulfilled.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:10 reveals that the enemy’s attack happens by God’s command, encouraging believers to persevere, trusting God’s ultimate control and purpose.

questions.question: What biblical principle about leadership and responsibility can be learned from how Hezekiah’s officials handled the Assyrian threats?
options: Leaders and their helpers must communicate honestly and faithfully report threats to the king.
They should ignore threats and avoid reporting them.
They should try to negotiate secretly with the enemy.
They should immediately surrender without informing the king.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders and their helpers must communicate honestly and faithfully report threats to the king.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:22 describes how Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn to report Rabshakeh’s words, showing responsible leadership and transparency.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 36, Rabshakeh spoke to Hezekiah’s officials only in a foreign language to prevent the people from understanding him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:11-13 shows that Rabshakeh first spoke in the Jewish language loudly so all the people could hear, aiming to intimidate and demoralize them, not to hide his message.

questions.question: True or False: Rabshakeh offered peace and provisions to the people if they surrendered to Assyria.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:16-17 records Rabshakeh inviting the people to make an agreement, enjoy their own vineyards, fig trees, and water, promising a land like their own if they surrendered.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Rabshakeh mocked Hezekiah’s trust in Egypt by saying it is like leaning on a ________, which pierces the hand.
questions.correctAnswer: broken reed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:6 describes the trust in Egypt as leaning on a broken reed that will pierce the hand, illustrating the danger of false confidence in unreliable help.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 36 teach us about the importance of witnessing and standing firm as a community of faith?
options: By showing the officials acting collectively with humility and obedience to the king’s command.
By having individuals act separately without coordination.
By rejecting all communication with outsiders.
By relying on personal strength rather than community support.
questions.correctAnswer: By showing the officials acting collectively with humility and obedience to the king’s command.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:3 and 36:21 show Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah working together and following the king’s instructions, demonstrating the value of unified, humble witness and faithfulness.

questions.question: What practical application about prayer and seeking God’s guidance is illustrated by Hezekiah’s response to the threat in Isaiah 36?
options: Hezekiah’s reliance on God’s word and refusal to trust in human alliances teaches believers to seek God’s guidance and pray for deliverance.
Hezekiah ignores the enemy and prays for his own strength only.
Hezekiah seeks advice only from military commanders.
Hezekiah makes a secret deal with the enemy.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah’s reliance on God’s word and refusal to trust in human alliances teaches believers to seek God’s guidance and pray for deliverance.
questions.explanation: The officials’ silence and report to the king (Isaiah 36:21, 22) imply Hezekiah’s trust in God’s protection, encouraging believers to depend on prayer and God’s guidance rather than worldly help.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 36.

questions.question: In Isaiah 36:1, in which year of King Hezekiah's reign did Sennacherib king of Assyria come against the fortified cities of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteenth year
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:1 explicitly states that it was in the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah that Sennacherib came up against the fortified cities of Judah.

questions.question: Who did the king of Assyria send from Lachish to Jerusalem with a great army, according to Isaiah 36:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Rabshakeh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:2 details that the king of Assyria sent Rabshakeh from Lachish to Jerusalem with a great army.

questions.question: What is the significance of Rabshakeh standing by the conduit of the upper pool in the highway of the fuller's field (Isaiah 36:2) in terms of ancient Near Eastern siege tactics?
options: It was a strategic water source near Jerusalem's walls
It was a place for treaty negotiations
It was the royal palace courtyard
It was the main gate of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It was a strategic water source near Jerusalem's walls
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh's choice of the conduit of the upper pool, a key water source near the city walls, was a psychological tactic to intimidate Jerusalem by demonstrating control over vital resources (Isaiah 36:2).

questions.question: Which three officials came forth to meet Rabshakeh as described in Isaiah 36:3?
options: Eliakim, Hilkiah’s son; Shebna the scribe; Joah, Asaph’s son
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Hilkiah’s son; Shebna the scribe; Joah, Asaph’s son
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:3 names these three officials as representatives who met Rabshakeh during the Assyrian delegation.

questions.question: Rabshakeh accuses Hezekiah of trusting in what 'broken reed' according to Isaiah 36:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:6 uses the metaphor of a broken reed to describe Egypt as unreliable, warning Hezekiah against trusting Pharaoh.

questions.question: In Isaiah 36:7, Rabshakeh challenges the people's trust in the LORD by referencing what specific action taken by Hezekiah?
options: Hezekiah's removal of high places and altars
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah's removal of high places and altars
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh points out that Hezekiah had removed altars and high places, implying that the LORD’s support might be uncertain (Isaiah 36:7).

questions.question: What offer does Rabshakeh make to Hezekiah in Isaiah 36:8 to entice him to submit?
options: Two thousand horses if Hezekiah can set riders on them
questions.correctAnswer: Two thousand horses if Hezekiah can set riders on them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:8 records Rabshakeh offering two thousand horses contingent on Hezekiah's ability to place riders on them, as a challenge to Judah's military capabilities.

questions.question: Rabshakeh claims in Isaiah 36:10 that his campaign against Judah was commanded by whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 36:10, Rabshakeh arrogantly claims that it is the LORD who has commanded him to attack Judah, attempting to portray his campaign as divinely sanctioned.

questions.question: Why do Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah request Rabshakeh to speak in the Syrian language rather than in Hebrew (Isaiah 36:11)?
options: So the people on the wall would not understand
Because they did not understand Hebrew
To confuse the people of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: So the people on the wall would not understand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:11 explains that the officials wanted Rabshakeh to speak in a language not understood by the people on the wall, to prevent panic or dissent.

questions.question: How does Rabshakeh respond to the request to speak in the Syrian language (Isaiah 36:12)?
options: He refuses and speaks in Hebrew loudly
He insults the officials and speaks in Hebrew
questions.correctAnswer: He refuses and speaks in Hebrew loudly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:12-13 shows Rabshakeh refusing to speak privately and instead loudly addresses the people in Hebrew, intending to intimidate the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What is the main message Rabshakeh delivers to the people of Jerusalem in Isaiah 36:14-15?
options: That Hezekiah cannot deliver them and the city will fall
That the LORD will protect them
That Egypt will come to their aid
That a secret alliance is being formed
questions.correctAnswer: That Hezekiah cannot deliver them and the city will fall
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh’s speech in Isaiah 36:14-15 is aimed at discouraging trust in Hezekiah and the LORD, asserting that the city will be delivered into Assyrian hands.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 36:18-19, Rabshakeh uses what argument to dissuade the people from trusting the LORD?
options: None of the gods of the nations have delivered their lands from Assyria
The walls of Jerusalem are weak
questions.correctAnswer: None of the gods of the nations have delivered their lands from Assyria
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh mocks the power of the LORD by comparing Him to the gods of other nations, none of whom have saved their lands from Assyria (Isaiah 36:18-19).

questions.question: What instruction did the king give to the officials regarding how to respond to Rabshakeh’s taunts (Isaiah 36:21)?
questions.correctAnswer: Answer him not a word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:21 states that the king commanded silence from the officials in response to Rabshakeh’s provocations.

questions.question: True or False: In Isaiah 36:22, the officials report Rabshakeh’s words to Hezekiah with their clothes torn as a sign of mourning and distress.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:22 describes how Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah came to Hezekiah with their clothes rent, indicating their deep distress as they reported Rabshakeh’s message.

questions.question: How does the Assyrian king’s message in Isaiah 36 reflect the ancient Near Eastern practice of psychological warfare?
options: By boasting of divine sanction and mocking religious faith
By immediately launching a surprise attack
By withdrawing troops to show mercy
questions.correctAnswer: By boasting of divine sanction and mocking religious faith
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh’s speech, claiming the LORD commanded him and mocking the gods of the nations (Isaiah 36:10, 18), exemplifies psychological warfare aimed at undermining Judah’s morale and faith.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 36 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 36 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, what did Sennacherib, king of Assyria, do to the fortified cities of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: He took them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:1 states that Sennacherib came up against all the defenced cities of Judah and took them. This shows the Assyrian king's aggression and judgment upon Judah, consistent with God's sovereign use of nations (cf. Isaiah 10:5-7, Jeremiah 25:9, Romans 13:1-4).

questions.question: Who did the king of Assyria send from Lachish to Jerusalem to confront King Hezekiah?
questions.correctAnswer: Rabshakeh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:2 identifies Rabshakeh as the official sent by the king of Assyria from Lachish to deliver his message to Hezekiah. This reflects the practice of imperial representatives confronting subject nations, highlighting themes of human power versus divine sovereignty (cf. 2 Kings 18:17, Daniel 2:37-38).

questions.question: What question did Rabshakeh ask Hezekiah’s officials regarding their confidence?
options: What confidence is this wherein thou trustest?
Why do you rebel against me?
questions.correctAnswer: What confidence is this wherein thou trustest?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:4 records Rabshakeh's challenge to Hezekiah's officials about their confidence, questioning the basis of their trust. This reflects a common human temptation to trust in worldly power rather than God (cf. Psalm 20:7, Jeremiah 17:5, Matthew 6:19-21).

questions.question: According to Rabshakeh, what is the 'staff of this broken reed' that Judah trusts in?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:6 uses the metaphor of a 'broken reed' to describe Egypt, warning that leaning on Egypt for help will result in harm. This points to the futility of relying on human alliances rather than God (cf. Isaiah 30:1-3, Psalm 118:8, Jeremiah 2:18).

questions.question: Rabshakeh accused Hezekiah of removing what from Judah and Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: High places and altars
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:7 mentions that Hezekiah had taken away high places and altars, centralizing worship in Jerusalem. This reflects Hezekiah's religious reforms to abolish idolatry, emphasizing true worship of the LORD (cf. 2 Kings 18:4, Deuteronomy 12:5-14, 2 Chronicles 31:1-21).

questions.question: What offer did Rabshakeh make to Hezekiah if he could set riders on the horses provided?
questions.correctAnswer: Two thousand horses
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:8 describes Rabshakeh's offer to provide two thousand horses if Hezekiah could set riders on them, mocking Judah's military capability. This reflects the Assyrian threat and the temptation to rely on military might instead of God (cf. Psalm 33:16-17, Jeremiah 17:7, Zechariah 4:6).

questions.question: What reason did Rabshakeh give for coming up against Judah?
options: The LORD said unto me, Go up against this land, and destroy it
To make a covenant with Hezekiah
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD said unto me, Go up against this land, and destroy it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:10 quotes Rabshakeh claiming divine authorization for the Assyrian campaign, illustrating the theological theme of God using pagan nations as instruments of judgment (cf. Isaiah 10:5-6, Habakkuk 1:5-11, Romans 9:17).

questions.question: Why did Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah request Rabshakeh to speak in the Syrian language?
options: So the people on the wall would not understand
Because they did not understand Hebrew
To show respect to the Assyrian king
questions.correctAnswer: So the people on the wall would not understand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:11 shows the officials asking Rabshakeh to speak in Syrian to conceal his message from the people on the wall, reflecting concerns about morale and the power of words (cf. Proverbs 18:21, 2 Corinthians 2:11).

questions.question: How did Rabshakeh respond to the request to speak in the Syrian language?
options: He refused and spoke in the Jews' language
He agreed and spoke in Syrian
He sent a written message instead
questions.correctAnswer: He refused and spoke in the Jews' language
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:12-13 narrate Rabshakeh's refusal and his loud proclamation in the Jews' language to directly intimidate the people, showing his confidence and disdain. This underscores spiritual warfare and opposition to God's people (cf. Ephesians 6:12, Psalm 91:5).

questions.question: What was Rabshakeh's message about trusting in the LORD to deliver Jerusalem?
options: Hezekiah will not be able to deliver you
The LORD will surely deliver you
You must trust only in the LORD
The LORD is powerless against me
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah will not be able to deliver you
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:14-15 records Rabshakeh's attempt to undermine faith in God by declaring Hezekiah unable to save. This presents a false view of God's sovereignty and power, which the Bible elsewhere affirms (cf. Psalm 124:8, Isaiah 43:13, Romans 8:31).

questions.question: What did Rabshakeh urge the people of Jerusalem to do instead of trusting Hezekiah or the LORD?
options: Make an agreement and come out to him
questions.correctAnswer: Make an agreement and come out to him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:16 challenges the people to surrender and enjoy their own produce under Assyrian rule, revealing the temptation to compromise faith under pressure (cf. Daniel 3:16-18, Hebrews 11:32-34).

questions.question: What rhetorical question did Rabshakeh ask to question the power of the LORD compared to the gods of other nations?
options: Hath any of the gods of the nations delivered his land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
Who is greater than the king of Assyria?
Can your God fight for you?
Does your God live among the nations?
questions.correctAnswer: Hath any of the gods of the nations delivered his land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:18 confronts the people with the impotency of foreign gods, aiming to diminish faith in their God. The biblical narrative consistently affirms the LORD as the true and living God who delivers His people (cf. Exodus 15:11, Deuteronomy 32:39, John 10:28).

questions.question: What was the response of Hezekiah’s officials to Rabshakeh’s taunts?
options: They held their peace and answered him not a word
They sent a message to the Assyrian king
questions.correctAnswer: They held their peace and answered him not a word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:21 notes the officials' silence as commanded by the king, illustrating restraint and trust in God's timing (cf. Psalm 37:7, Isaiah 41:10, Ecclesiastes 3:7).

questions.question: What did Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah do after hearing Rabshakeh’s words?
options: They tore their clothes and reported to Hezekiah
They went to consult the priests
questions.correctAnswer: They tore their clothes and reported to Hezekiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 36:22 describes how the officials rent their clothes in mourning and brought Rabshakeh's message to Hezekiah, showing the seriousness of the threat and human grief in the face of trial (cf. Genesis 37:34, 2 Samuel 1:11-12, Joel 2:13).

questions.question: What does Rabshakeh’s speech in this chapter reveal about the nature of evil’s challenge to God’s people?
options: It seeks to undermine trust in God by appealing to human strength and political alliances
It encourages repentance and faith in the true God
It respects God's sovereignty and offers peace
It seeks to affirm the power of God through miracles
questions.correctAnswer: It seeks to undermine trust in God by appealing to human strength and political alliances
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh’s message (Isaiah 36:4-20) is a sophisticated attempt to discredit faith in God by promoting reliance on Egypt and Assyrian power, demonstrating the spiritual warfare against God's people. This is consistent with biblical teaching on the devil’s tactics (cf. 2 Corinthians 10:3-5, Ephesians 6:11-12, James 4:7).
